awd_titl_txt: Symbolic Powers, Configurations of Linear Spaces, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is in the area of commutative algebra, with connections to algebraic geometry and computational algebra. Commutative algebra has applications in a range of areas, from statistics to game theory, from robotics to string theory.  The main theme of this project is the study of configurations of linear subspaces, such as finite collections of lines in the plane. These problems are classically motivated by algebraic geometry and have received renewed interest in the last fifteen years. Despite a rapidly growing body of work, there is still much progress needed to understand the subtle behavior of these configurations. This research program aims to take advantage of the combinatorial structure inherently present in this context. The project will also study potential applications of this work to coding theory.

The common thread for the investigations in this project concerns the asymptotic properties of symbolic powers. One goal of the project is the determination of certain invariants that measure these asymptotic properties (resurgence, Waldschmidt constants). Another goal is to characterize families of ideals that display extremal behavior with respect to the containment between ordinary and symbolic powers. Among the tools to be employed are methods involving the study of Rees algebras, minimal free resolutions, and local cohomology for powers of ideals. Another line of inquiry will consider the symbolic powers for singular loci of line arrangements, or more generally hyperplane arrangements, with special emphasis on reflection arrangements because of their additional structure. Despite their undoubted theoretical significance, not much is known about the practical applications of symbolic powers. The investigator and collaborators plan to start an investigation on the implications of this recent progress on symbolic powers from the point of view of applied algebraic geometry. Some computational tools in the form of scripts for the computer algebra system Macaulay will be developed to aid with the inquiry.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on fundamental research in non-linear algebra in response to current challenges from algebraic geometry. Geometrically, the question motivating this research asks to find polynomial functions vanishing to a prescribed order at every point of a given algebraic set. A particular emphasis is placed in this project on algebraic sets that are unions of linear spaces, that is, points, lines, planes, or higher-dimensional analogues in a projective space. The approach taken is via commutative algebra, where the answer to the previously mentioned question can be phrased in the language of symbolic power ideals. Thus, the major goals of the project revolve around gaining a better understanding of symbolic powers of homogeneous ideals in polynomial rings. 

 

The most important research outcomes can be grouped in the following broad directions:

1. Theoretical results include a study of the containment problem relating the families of symbolic powers  and ordinary powers of ideals. A major achievement in this direction obtained in the framework of this project is a partial solution to the containment problem for ideals defining the singular loci of hyperplane arrangements (see B. Drabkin and A. Seceleanu  Singular loci of reflection arrangements and the containment problem, Math Z., 2021). Other notable results focus on the homological properties of symbolic power ideals as well as on bringing tools from linear optimization, convex geometry, and combinatorics to bear on the study of symbolic powers of monomial ideals.

2. Novel applications of algebraic techniques developed in the framework of this project include generalizing the notion of Hamming distance from coding theory (see S. Cooper, A. Seceleanu, Ş. Tohăneanu, M. Vaz Pinto and R. Villarreal, Generalized minimum distance functions and algebraic invariants of Geramita ideals, Adv. in Appl. Math., 2020) and formulating new methods to produce implicit equations of surfaces used in computer-aided design based upon virtual homological algebra (see E. Duarte and A. Seceleanu, Implicitization of tensor product surfaces via virtual projective resolutions, Math. Comput., 2020).

3. Development of computer algebra software tailored to the above tasks was integral to the success of the project. This code was contributed to and is distributed freely with the computer algebra system for research in commutative algebra and algebraic geometry Macaulay2.


The broader impacts of this project consist in training the next generation of mathematicians and supporting women in mathematics. Specifically three graduate students and more than fifty undergraduate students participated in research endeavors supported by this project. Two of these graduate students have already completed their PhD. Another graduate student benefited from an industry internship focusing on medical applications of computer vision sponsored by an INTERN supplemental award. The PI mentored large groups of undergraduate students in collaborative summer research projects in 2020 and 2021. She also co-led a group of female mathematicians in a team research project under the auspices of the Women in Commutative Algebra research network of the Association for Women in Mathematics.
